ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The CalARP Program developed for this facility is designed to prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating and implementing our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in design, construction, start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the CalARP Program regulation and the OSHA PSM Standard.  This comprehensive program has been developed to enable all those who may be affected to be able to identify and understand the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration process.

Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the regulation.  This Program document, as well as the other documents and reports that are created pursuant to this Program, are made accessible to our employees and to other affected persons in accordance with applicable requirements and the provisions of the CalARP Program.  See Policy Statement for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program at the end of Chapter 1 (Overview) of the program manual.

Emergency response measures have been developed and implemented for proper and safe evacuation and notifications to outside emergency responders.  These measures reflect the established policies of this facility for ensuring the health and safety of all employees and those who may be on site or in the area in the event of an accidental release of ammonia.

This CalARP Program is regularly reviewed and updated as required, and whenever necessary to reflect new or modified tasks and procedures.  Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream corporate personnel ensure that safety and environmental policies are implemented at local company facilities by conducting periodic compliance inspections.

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The only regulated substance at this facility subject to the Acciden

tal Release Prevention programs or the Process Safety Management Standards is anhydrous ammonia in the refrigeration system.

Facility Description

 The Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Distribution Center is located at 1351 DuPont Court in Manteca, California at the end of DuPont Court.  The facility lies approximately 500 yards west of State Highway 99 and 500 yards north of State Highway 120 near the intersection of the two highways.  The facility is situated in an area comprised primarily of light industrial facilities, commercial and office areas, some agricultural lands, and residential areas.  See Figure 1 for the Site Location Map of this facility.

This facility stores ice cream products for distribution under approximately 98,000 square feet of total warehouse space, with approximately 70,000 square feet of refrigerated space.  The remaining areas include office areas, the control room, and the engine room.  There is no manufacturing at this facility.  See Figure 2 for the Facility Map.

The distribution center employs approximately 60 people and the refrigeration system operates 24 hours per day.
 
Process Description

This facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a heat transfer fluid in the plant refrigeration system.  The system is a single-stage, multi-suction, economized mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes recirculated liquid feed to evaporator coils.  Cooling is required for the 10A?F Shipping Dock and for the -20A?F freezer.  The system charge is approximately 13,000 lbs.

One high-temperature screw compressor provides suction and compression for the high temperature cooling, while two low-temperature screw compressors serve the low-temperature cooling requirements.  A swing screw compressor can back-up either the high-temperature or low-temperature requirements as needed.

The heat of compression in the high-pressure compressor discharge is removed in the evaporative condenser.  The condenser drains high-pressure liquid to the thermosiphon / high-

m is not manned 24 hours but is managed and controlled by the system PLC, safety switches, level switches, alarms, and compressor microprocessors.  An autodialer initiates a call list, including the refrigeration contractor technician, in the event of system operating deviations.  All personnel are trained in the proper emergency response procedures, specifically the procedures called out in the site Emergency Action Plan for response to ammonia releases.  The Plan includes notification and evacuation protocols.

There is an oil pot at each recirculator and each oil pot vessel is equipped with a self-closing spring-loaded drain valve for safety.  All pressure vessels in the system have dual safety relief valves (SRV's) to protect the respective vessel against overpressure conditions.  All SRV's relieve to an ammonia diffusion tank via a common discharge piping system.  An auto purger removes non-condensibles and air as required to maintain an efficient refrigeration process.

Evaporator piping and valve trains are located on the roof, while the freezer evaporators are located in rooftop penthouse units above the freezer and the dock evaporators are suspended from bar joists inside the dock area.  The evaporator coils are defrosted with hot gas from the high stage discharge line.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The release prevention elements included in the CalARP Program Manual provide the critical elements for preventing accidental releases.  Anhydrous ammonia is present in the refrigeration system above the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. and is, therefore, subject to the OSHA PSM Standard.  The PSM Standard elements have been adopted to satisfy the Program 3 release prevention steps for anhydrous ammonia.  Specifically, the elements of the release prevention program are:

1.    Employee Participation Program
2.    Process Safety Information
3.    Process Hazard Analysis
4.    Operating Procedures
5.    Training
6.    Co

ntractors
7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review
8.    Mechanical Integrity
9.    Hot Work
10.    Management of Change
11.    Incident Investigation
12.    Emergency Planning & Response
13.    Compliance Audit
14.    Trade Secrets (no trade secrets are involved in this process)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at the Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Manteca facility in the past five years that are subject to the CalARP or EPA Accidental Release Prevention Program reporting requirements.
 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream maintains an Emergency Action Plan as described in the CalARP Program Manual.  The emergency response measures primarily include the safe evacuation of all personnel and notification to outside emergency responders.  Incidental releases that do not pose an imminent safety hazard may be abated by contractor employees who are trained to provide such a response, are wearing the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), and are authorized by Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream to perform such activities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Modifications to this system are implemented through the Management of Change, as a result of Process Hazard Analyses recommendations, Compliance Audit findings, Incident Investigations, regulatory audits, and self-discovery.  Deficiencies are scheduled for correction and completed in a timely manner.

Current plans to improve safety include:

1.    Additional and modified Standard Operating Procedures
2.    Minor improvements for labeling of equipment, valves, and piping
3.    Valve lockout and tagging modifications
4.    Improved equipment access for maintenance activities
5.    Additional emergency shower and eyewash stations
6.    Minor modifications to system drawings
7.    Updated pressure relief system calculations
8.    Detector and alarm modifications
9.    System control verifications
10.    Piping and equipment insulation repairs
11.    Additional written preventive maintenance procedures
